Fifteen of these spectral reels span the years 1895 to 1901, each one a conjuration of illusion wrought by the alchemy of early editing. My study was a meditation on the poetics of these celluloid phantasms and a dissection of the evolutionary aberrations that emerged in their latter days. At the dawn of the century, these films were as bound to their stages as a moth to the flame, their worlds contained within the rigid confines of a frontal proscenium. The camera, unyielding and static, captured long and medium shots with the fidelity of a solemn witness. Each film a singular breath, one shot, one film.

Yet, as the century turned, a few bold visions dared to fracture this orthodoxy, introducing the radical notion of multiple shots. Still, most adhered to the stage-bound artifice, the camera never straying from its steadfast post to follow the actors’ steps. This immobility, a vestige of theatre and vaudeville, shackled the figures to a lateral dance, side-to-side, never towards the lens. Consider Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel (1900), where actors enter from the right, tracing a path along the horizontal axis, the camera unmoving, a dispassionate observer as they vanish beyond the frame.

The proscenium's grip dictated the use of long shots, with medium shots a mere whisper and close-ups an unheard plea. The frames echoed the theatre's grandeur, where the audience's eye embraced the entirety of the spectacle, bounded by the stage’s borders. Actors remained in the midground tableau, close-ups forsaken in the dawn of film.

These early trick films bore the constraint of a single shot as their narrative vessel, a limitation that confined their length to a minute or less, dictated by the clockwork of frames per second. Their tales were brief and wondrous, vaudeville's magic acts captured with little narrative ambition. Yet, the illusion was a clever deceit, for what seemed a single shot was often a tapestry of many, woven together to conjure apparitions and vanishings. In The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots (1895), the illusion fractures under scrutiny, revealing the seam where Mary's spectral head is severed from her body. Though to the viewer's eye, it remains a singular, haunting vision.

In the gatherings of shadowed halls and timeworn spires, the Gothic Novel stands as a contradiction of old and new, a literary oxymoron as Ian Watt notes in his chronicles of its ascent. This Gothic form, maligned and exalted in equal measure, has been accused of lacking depth even as it conjures the 'terrible sublime' that Burke would speak of in hushed tones. The birth of this literary specter traces back to Horace Walpole's The Castle of Otranto, a conjuring of both ancient and modern romance to forge a new path through the world of letters. Walpole, with a craftsman’s eye, wove together the old theatrics and the mimicry of nature that the modern novel offered, and in this alchemy, he penned what he would call "A Gothic Story."

The Gothic genre is a tapestry woven from the threads of medieval theatre, architecture, and traditions. Even as The Castle of Otranto met the world, the word "Gothic" bore the weight of many meanings, stretching across peoples, styles, and ages. It seemed a relic, unsophisticated in the harsh gaze of modernity's march. Yet it was this very mingling of the theatrical and the novel's new form, with its gaze into the heart of its characters, that let the Gothic endure, ever ancient yet forever new to eyes far removed from its birth.

Among the shadows of Gothic thought, the specter of Chivalry walks, a relic of medieval honor and the knightly path. In The Castle of Otranto, this old chivalric code is both preserved and transformed. For Gothic scribes, the idea of chivalry held a sacred importance—it evoked the noble knight, steadfast and true, a stark contrast to the absence of such ideals they perceived around them. Through these chivalric echoes, the Gothic past became a canvas of idealization, a hint of Romanticism yet to come, an attempt to cast a light upon the present’s shadows. Walpole, amidst the turmoil of his times, despaired at the world’s trajectory. Engulfed by the political storm and its accusations, he may have pondered the loss of the Gothic era's moral compass within the hearts of his contemporaries. This musing finds a face in Frederic, a character hewn from the stone of chivalric tradition.

Frederic's tale is told before his entry, painted in images of chivalry. A prince once, his life marked by suffering and tragedy, lost to the world by infidel hands. In Frederic, the gallant knight takes form, an image stretched to the edge of excess, heralding the Gothic penchant for the grandiose.

In the dim recesses of industry, where the hum of machinery echoes like a distant thunder, there lies the intricate dance of supply chain management. It's a procession, from the moment a customer’s desire is whispered into the ether, through the raw, unformed materials, till the goods are birthed, handed over from one unseen hand to another, till they reach that final resting place in the consumer’s grasp. This notion, this orchestration of movement and time, was laid forth in 1982 by a man named Keith Oliver, who envisioned the path of goods as a tapestry woven with intent, planning, and control, all to meet the whims of want in a manner swift and sure. Six pillars uphold this edifice: production, supply, inventory, location, transportation, and the ghostly strands of information that tie them all.

The forge of production sits at the heart of this process, the molten core from which all else flows. It is here that the when and why and where and how are etched into the stone of intent. The managers, those stewards of commerce, peer into the market, that roiling sea of demand, to glean the desires of the masses. They chart their course, deciding what shall be made and in what measure, choosing the ground where these things shall spring into being, ever mindful of the twin gods of volume and quality, and the needful satisfaction of those who await. And once the place is set, the gears of scheduling turn, the machines are tended, for in the minutiae lies the salvation or the downfall of the enterprise. Missteps here are costly, and the reckoning comes swift. In my own wanderings through the labyrinthine aisles of Wal-Mart and Target, I have seen the doctrine laid bare—a uniformity in attire, a precision in the reception of goods, a testament to the power of outlined processes to stave off the chaos that ever lurks at the edges.

Supply, the second pillar, stands in the shadow of production, casting its own light upon the path. It is the art of choosing, of deciding which capabilities to cultivate within the walls of the facility and which to entrust to the hands of others. A single product may be born in many places, each division a cog in the greater machine, each with its own tools, its own people, its own craft. The manager’s eye must discern which piece fits where, or if the work shall be cast out to others, to partners in this grand endeavor. For in outsourcing lies the promise of velocity—the speed and grace to provide what is needed, when it is needed, without the burden of excessive cost. And so the dance continues, a delicate balance of power and trust, the symphony of supply chain management ever playing to the tune of demand.

Victorian novels, with their ornate tapestries of detail and their unyielding gaze upon the aristocracy, chart a course through the history of an age. Yet from amidst this grand procession emerge two tales that wander from the well-trodden path: Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights. These novels, with their enigmatic mysteries and the strange, bewildering turns of the bizarre, carve out a realm where characters are not merely drawn but etched deep, their motives and hearts laid bare under the scrutiny of shadows and dreams.

And in that shadowed world, Oliver, beset by visions, walks again with the specters of Sikes and Crackit. Their quarrels echo in his mind, a relentless clamor, even as he finds himself speaking to them in the solitude of his thoughts. The sudden crack of gunfire seizes him, cries and shouts erupting as though the very night itself had awakened. Lights flash before his eyes, chaos surrounds him, and some unseen force sweeps him away. Through this tumult, there persists a constant ache, a torment that gnaws at him with an unyielding hunger.

In these novels, the dreams and visions serve as portals to inner truths, each one a revelation of the soul's hidden landscape. In Oliver Twist, the strange visions tear at the veil of the ordinary, exposing the raw nerves of Oliver's existence. As he relives the shooting in the depths of his mind, the scene unfolds with dreamlike clarity, a testament to his powerlessness against the forces that shape his fate. The hands that bear him away are unseen, the pain an ever-present specter, now entwined with fear rather than shrouded in the numbness of shock. The question looms large: whose design has wrought this suffering upon him? For it is not of his own making. This episode underscores the futility of Oliver's struggle for agency, even as his very life hangs by a thread. The specter of defeat hovers over him, as if old Fagin's shadow had begun to creep into his soul, urging him to surrender to despair, to abandon the fight. Yet somewhere within, a flicker remains, a quiet defiance that refuses to be entirely extinguished.

The day passed off—day! There was no day; it vanished as swiftly as it came—and night descended once more, a night endless in its dreadful hush, fleeting in its swift passage of hours.

Years back, I found myself in the halls and classrooms of an after school refuge, a place where young minds, elementary and eager, came to wrestle with their lessons. My own inclinations lay in the labyrinth of language, English and the written word my favored realms. It was there that a teacher sought my aid for a boy named Adrian, a lad of perhaps eight or nine years, adrift in the sea of letters. His struggle, it seemed, was not with the words themselves but with the very symbols that made them. Some letters he grasped as if by instinct, others eluded him entirely, a dance of comprehension and confusion. He was Latino, of that there was no question, yet his English was flawless, untainted by any accent. We battled onward, he and I, until the day his mother darkened the doorway. I was watching over the few left behind, when she arrived, her speech a cascade of Spanish, a tongue I barely managed to navigate. But in those halting exchanges, the truth fell upon me with the weight of a revelation: Adrian's battle was with the alphabet itself, not the reading. Whether this epiphany served him well, I cannot say, but in my heart, I hope he found his way.

I recount this tale to illuminate the chasm of language that looms in our schools, a chasm deepened here in the lands of California. It serves to remind that the barriers are not always where we expect them. A child may speak the language of his peers with ease yet find the page an insurmountable wall. This is a truth we must reckon with. So, what is to be done? In Adrian's case, the answer lay in the simple act of tutoring, a focus on the letters and their sounds. Yet for those whose tongues are not yet shaped by English, the path is fraught with complexity. There is no single remedy. The dual language system, the immersion, the tutors, the ESL classes, each a tool, none a cure by itself. The answer lies in their union.

The dual language path is a worthy venture, not merely for the children of Spanish tongues, but for all. Studies speak of children in bilingual programs surpassing their peers, an achievement not confined to the few. Fear lingers, a specter of wasted effort, a belief that most gain nothing. But this is a falsehood. Make these programs the standard, not the exception, and all will rise. Yet, how to achieve this? Must we demand our teachers speak in two tongues? No, such a demand is folly. But there is no reason we cannot bring forth a cadre of aides, tutors, call them what you will, who bridge this gap with their bilingual voices.

From the first whispers of consciousness we are told of a force greater than ourselves, vast and unknowable. Some are led to chapels and others to synagogues, while others seek within the silence of their own hearts. We are handed down the faiths of our fathers and many accept them without question, yet there are those who turn away, dismissing the unseen in their self-centered world. In the course of our lives, we may embrace one creed and later cast it aside for another. We walk various paths, each seeking to understand our place in the cosmos through the lens of our own spiritual perceptions. In the shadows, we search for a light to guide us to the dawn.

A cardinal, my father said when I inquired of his favored bird. We sat on the porch, the rain drumming on the tin roof above, sharing cigarettes. The water poured from the gutters, drowning the plants that clung to the edge of the porch. His eyes were fixed on the rain, lost in a gaze that seemed to see beyond the present. He had grown gaunt these past months, his clothes hanging loose as if they belonged to another man. His hair had thinned, a sparse memory of what once was. Still, he stared into the rain, never meeting my eyes. I felt the solitude between us, the fear of speaking the words that would make real what we both knew. I embraced him, then settled back, drawing my chair closer, and joined him in watching the rain fall in the dim light of June’s end.

He left this world that December, five days past my twenty-second year. The poison and the fire of treatment had not lessened his pain, but only stretched his days beyond the doctors’ reckonings; what worth in such prolonged suffering I could not say. I questioned the nature of a God who would allow such cruelty. Alone in the darkness, I found no prayers left in me. If there was a God, I felt he had turned his ear from me long ago.

I could not bear witness to his passing from this life. I chose not to. I wished to remember him in life, not in the shadow of death. I knew him, perhaps better than any, and knew he would not want me there in those final moments. So I lay curled in my bed for three days, waiting for the news that never came.

No one thought to call.

In the rolling fields of Caroline where the soil lay dark and fertile, there stood a man named John Taylor, who with the fervor of a prophet, championed the cause of Republicanism. A farmer by trade, yet his voice echoed in the chambers of power, a testament to his fervent belief in the liberty of men and the restraint of government. His conviction in the agrarian way colored every word he spoke on sovereignty, on the sanctity of the Constitution, and even upon the courts of law.

John Taylor saw in the young nation of the United States a canvas unspoiled, unblemished by the burdens of old traditions. Here was a land where men could craft with their own hands a government of self-rule. He held fast to the natural rights of man, these rights entwined like the roots of old trees, so that in denying one, the whole would wither. Such rights, he declared, must remain out of the grasp of any mortal government. In the brutish state of nature, it was the strong of arm and dark of mind who thrived, but within the bounds of civilization, such must not be.

To forge this society, Taylor said, the government must reckon with the dual nature of man, his capacity for both good and evil. His creed was simple, yet stern, that all virtues and vices of governance were but reflections of human nature. Good principles, he claimed, were those that safeguarded private land, nurtured the crops that sprang from it, and turned away from the lure of unchecked commerce. A government rooted in such principles would stand fair, despite the inevitable sway of those who lead with greed. Self-interest, he mused, drives all men, yet it turns foul when it births enclaves that flourish at the cost of others. A vigilant government was needed to keep man's darker instincts in check, ever wary of the creeping shadow of ill principles.

Among the chorus of Republican voices, Taylor's was steadfast, calling for a Constitution held tight to its written word. He envisioned a Federal government constrained, with powers no greater than those written clear upon the parchment. An expansive government meant an expensive one, and he saw in that the seeds of tyranny. Yet he warned against a mere literal reading of the text, for without the light of the framers' intent, corruption could easily take root. To Taylor, the Declaration of Independence was the true heart of the nation, a testament not to a singular entity, but to a union of sovereign states, each with its own soul.

The world lay still before me, a tableau untouched by time, and I gazed upon it with a mind as unyielding and indifferent as the earth itself. No tether to abstraction disturbed my view, no whisper of understanding, for mine was a study of the visible and nothing beyond. Thoughts drifted like ghosts, ephemeral and unclaimed, the mind a smooth stone upon which the stream of perception flowed, untroubled and clear.

Once, at the urging of an artist I’d known, I procured a book, The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain. I’d longed to draw since boyhood, six years tender and yearning for the secrets held in a pencil's line. The book promised to reveal all, from the mystery of graphite to the alchemy of perception. It taught, among other things, the framing of a picture, to distill chaos into clarity—a bowl of fruit on a table, a universe contained within a frame.

Yet there, before the bowl, I stood unable to conjure such a frame. Overwhelmed I was, awestruck and silent. The greats had their phases and palettes—Picasso his blue, Monet his green, the masters their prismed hues. And here I stood, at the dawn of my own work, Work in Brown.

My fingers found the instrument of my art, muscles taut and obedient, and the air parted as my will became form. Water danced, clear and sure, flecks of existence surrendered to the void. Muscles clenched again, more insistent, and the hand drove the handle down. Still, the brown mass clung stubbornly, an unwelcome guest in porcelain confines.

With mop in hand, stance firm, and a tie strangling my neck, I surveyed the crude testament left behind in the Rite Aid restroom. Flush after futile flush, and moments of quiet reflection passed, until I reached for the paper, a makeshift gauntlet forming around my hand. Straightening, then bending, I plunged into the bowl, a mother reclaiming her Thanksgiving fowl...

The roads become a battleground where the young meet their end, their lives snuffed out behind the wheel. There's a confluence of factors that shape this grim ledger of statistics for the youngest of drivers in America. The National Institutes of Health speak of the adolescent mind, unripe and unready for the perils of the open road. Inexperience, too, stands at the core, a silent specter leading them to their doom. It is this lack of experience that not only brings about fatal collisions but an increase in vehicles overturned, a reckless speed, and the veering off into oblivion.

When they gather with their kin, the outcome is far more dire, a truth evident to any soul with a shred of sense, for these young riders often travel in packs. A study by the Southern California Injury Prevention Research Center reveals a stark correlation: the age of those riding alongside and the frequency of wrecks upon the road.

In places like California, the law seeks to shield these fledgling drivers by imposing provisional licenses that curtail their hours and banish other young passengers from their company. Yet these provisional measures are but a patch upon a greater wound. The truth is plain: these youngest among us, by any measure of statistics, are ill-prepared to shoulder the weight of the wheel. Psychologist Marvin Zuckerman holds that even eighteen is too tender an age for the granting of a full license. USA Today bears witness to his findings, revealing a penchant in those not yet twenty to court danger for the heady rush it imparts. It stands to reason then, to defer the granting of this privilege until the fever of thrill-seeking begins to wane. If we persist in bestowing licenses upon these young souls, the carnage will not cease; the death toll shall swell to unthinkable numbers in the coming years. As the children of the Baby Boomers come of age to drive, millions more will take to the highways.

The crafting of laws to address this need not be a complex affair. Schools might continue the instruction of driving to prepare those who will one day take the wheel, yet none younger than eighteen ought to command a motor vehicle. A provisional permit could still be given in the time before a full license is awarded, with practical training hours mandated. The number of hours might mirror what states currently require; in California, six hours of wheel-time and fifty in the company of an elder. Given the deadly data drawn from across the nation, a uniform law to guard young drivers would be a reasonable—and I dare say effective—step in securing the safety of our youth.

Such legislation is not a novel concept, but one of necessity and sense.

In the quiet corridors of the mind's vast expanse, where shadows whisper and echoes linger, there lies a disorder by the name of Central Auditory Processing Disorder, or CAPD, a malady not of the ears but of the soul's perception. It is here that we begin, unfolding the tale of a brain's struggle to make sense of the sounds that dance around it. First, we must define this affliction, and then, we shall peer into the means by which it is known, marked by signs and signals like distant smoke on the horizon. Lastly, we turn our gaze to the classrooms, where teachers, like weary sentinels, seek to guide those beset by CAPD through the fog of misunderstanding.

CAPD, or Auditory Processing Disorder as some have called it, speaks to the enigma of the central nervous system's dance with the auditory world. The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, in their wisdom of 2005, spoke of it as the CNS's art of utilizing sound, where the fault lies not in hearing but in the alchemy of translation. The ears hear, yet the mind falters, unable to separate the song from the silence, the voice from the void.

In the annals of history, its earliest echoes resound from the mid-1950s, cloaked in the name of 'auditory imperception.' It was then that pioneers such as Bocca, Calearo, and Cassinari began their work, crafting tests in the year 1954. Kimura, in 1961, brought forth dichotic testing, weaving a model to unveil the mysteries of the central auditory nervous system. A gathering of minds in 1977 kindled the fires of inquiry into the children who bore this burden.

CAPD reveals itself in myriad forms, a specter of sound and silence. The afflicted may wander through the world unable to discern sound's origin, or fail to tell one noise from another. Patterns of sound elude them, and the cadence of speech, with its subtle shifts, remains a riddle. The past sound is swallowed by the present, and the clues that others weave into meaning are lost upon them, as is the sequence of auditory events.

To diagnose this specter, one must embark on a journey of observation, through the systematic witnessing of listening and the trials of auditory function. Audiologists, SLPs, and psychologists are the seekers, wielding questionnaires and surveys, their eyes keen upon the behavior of the listener. Yet, no single test holds the key, no cause is known, and the path to understanding remains shrouded. Tests present a cacophony, asking of the listener a deciphering of words and numbers, while others delve deeper, recording the responses within the ear's hidden chambers.

In the end, CAPD is a silent struggle, a battle waged within, where the ears are but the gatekeepers to a mind that seeks to understand the world it hears, yet finds itself lost amidst the echoes.

In the pursuit of an education in social work, my path leads toward the Division of Family and Children Services, a road marked by the desire to mend what has been broken, to shield the young who have known only neglect or abuse, and to offer a hand to families adrift in the storm. The values I carry into this field are more than mere words; they are the bricks and mortar of my being—service, respect, an unwavering ethical compass, a commitment to better the bonds between people, and a relentless drive to hone my skills so that I remain ever worthy of the task. These values are not solely the province of the social worker; they are the quiet truth of who I am.

From my earliest days, the longing to aid others was a constant companion, though the road ahead lay obscured by shadows. High school and college unfolded before me, a parade of souls fleeing from their own shadows, some stumbling into the arms of poor solace. Witness to these struggles, I turned my steps toward a Bachelor’s degree in Psychology. Yet the path remained elusive, and so I paused upon graduating from Piedmont College in 2009. That summer, fate led me to a friend’s home, where a boy of sixteen sat upon her couch, his eyes wide with the fear of one seeking refuge from the cruelties of his own blood. The tale unfolded—an escape from abuse—and the next dawn brought news that he had called the law to stand against his kin. I went to that place where his parents dwelt, seeking to lend aid, and spoke my concerns to the officers who could do little more than listen. They bid me speak with the parents, and I did, the truth of my fresh degree a thin armor as I faced their nervous words, their justifications for what the boy had done. In that moment, the thought took root within me—a calling to the work of healing such "simple" disputes.

In this calling, there is also the fierce heart of social justice. Society proclaims the worth of the individual, yet in its mourning for the lost, it clings to traditions that bind rather than liberate. If we weep for those who pass, why do we shackle ourselves to the sameness of all? I am an individual, and I reject the chains that would make me otherwise. In the halls of high school and college, I raised my voice against the injustices I saw—my hair a palette of defiance, my clothes a banner of self, my ears adorned beyond the ordinary. I stood with the Gay Straight Bisexual Alliance, stood against the specter of racism and discrimination, whenever and wherever they reared their heads. For social justice is my creed, and I shall not cease in my protest against the injustices of this world.

In the dim corridor of human understanding, there lies the restless specter of insomnia, a disorder as ancient as the stars and as confounding as the shifting sands. This paper, like a lone traveler, seeks to unravel the tangled threads of its origins, peering through the lenses of the Biological and Sociocultural models. The biological model casts its gaze upon the bloodlines, the inheritance of genes and the medical tapestry woven through the flesh. Meanwhile, the Sociocultural model turns its eye to the world outside, the interplay of environment, race, and the unyielding march of socioeconomic forces. This review, a journey through the night, examines the chosen research, explaining, critiquing, and laying bare the strengths and weaknesses found therein.

Sleep disorders, those silent thieves of the night, come in many forms. They may stand alone as primary disorders or walk hand in hand with the shadows of mental affliction. The Dyssomnias, those guardians of sleep's gate, include Primary Insomnia, Primary Hypersomnia, and Narcolepsy, each a tale of its own. Primary Insomnia, a thief of slumber, while Primary Hypersomnia, a struggle to remain awake, both haunting their victims for no less than a month. Narcolepsy, with its sudden descents into the abyss, speaks of cataplexy and the automatic descent into dreams. The Parasomnias, in contrast, are specters of the night, causing nightmares, terrors, and sleepwalking, each a dance of the mind's shadows. The disorders tethered to mental afflictions, linked to the Axis I and Axis II, weave another story. This review lingers on insomnia, a focus upon the biological and sociocultural realms.

The biological model, a study of the codes within us, speaks of genes, heritable whispers, and the physiological web that binds. In the hypothalamus, neurons laced with orexin hold the keys to the kingdom of sleep and wakefulness. Studies with mice, those tiny wanderers of science, reveal GABAB receptors on these neurons, gatekeepers of slumber and alertness. Activation of the GABAA receptor ushers in sleep, while its silence brings forth anxiety and wakefulness. Baclofen, a GABAB agonist, lengthens the night's embrace (Matsuki et al., 2009). These findings, etched in the annals of research, suggest that the mice's tale may echo in the human heart. The genetic and environmental underpinnings of the GABAB receptor unveil a truth: its absence or malfunction may render sleep elusive. Socioculturally, if this phenotype is passed down, it may cast a shadow over life's endeavors, dimming the prospects of learning, work, and the daily grind of existence. And so, the study of insomnia, a journey through the darkness, seeks to illuminate the path forward.

I've roamed these grounds at University Park for nigh on two and a half years now. The corridors of time marked by four and a half semesters. For many and myself among them, the labyrinth of campus is a trial. My first year saw me nestled in an East Halls dormitory, perched at the easternmost edge of this scholar's domain, save for the stadium and Bryce Jordan Center's vastness. From my quarters in Stuart Hall to the distant precincts of Willard building, a pilgrimage to the heart of campus demanded twenty-five minutes or more, a journey aggravated by the whims of State College weather. In conversation with an alumnus, a soul not much older than myself, I gleaned tales of yore when East Halls stood apart, isolated by fields of barren earth. Now the void is filled, sports fields and colossal structures like the new Creamery and health services building rising up, apartments encircling them. As the campus sprawls ever outward, the burden of distance grows heavier. How best to traverse this widening expanse? The answer lies in the bicycle. Yet the bicycle alone is but half the battle. Riders must mount them, and the paths must welcome their wheels.

I spoke with a friend, one who had recently returned to the saddle after years away. He pondered aloud why he ever dismounted. "Bikes are grand," he declared. "Once, it wasn't the fashion to ride, but it's the only way to roam." Beyond fortifying the body, the bicycle is a paragon of efficiency. A humble bowl of oatmeal and the turn of a pedal can carry you thirty miles or more. Like many a student, I've taken residence off campus, distances akin to those dormitories. The wisest choice I've made this year was to acquire a bike. Each day, my path leads to Thomas building, a place that demands twenty-five minutes on foot from my door. A bicycle reduces that time to five, if I am swift and the road favors me. Yet the straightforward path of Pollock Road is fraught, a challenge whether mounted or on foot. There are merits in walking, but time is a luxury I do not possess. Without my bike, walking would be my sole recourse, a drain of thirty to forty minutes each day. Hours lost each week, time I cannot afford to squander.

In Aldous Huxley's dark vision of a world remade by the hands of men, he lays bare the creeping machinations of technology and the relentless march of capitalism, crafting a realm where the soul is subjugated to the whims of the machine. This brave new world, a place where the collective voice drowns out the solitary whisper, molds its people from birth to seek only the fleeting balm of immediate pleasure. Within this tapestry, the citizens are revealed as mere pieces in a grandiose game, their minds shackled to the dictates of the World Controller. Through the lens of Marxist thought, one glimpses Huxley's wary eye cast upon the constructs of his age. The jargon of Marxism—homogeny, reification—lurks within the narrative, underscoring the novel's commentary on the flaws of the burgeoning economy that rose around him.

In this satire of capitalism, the specter of false consciousness looms large. The common folk, blind to the chains that bind them to their economic fates, pursue self-interest in a dance orchestrated by unseen hands. This, the fruit of ideological dominion over the masses, stands starkly in Huxley's world. The Delta, the Gamma, and their ilk, robbed of true volition, are driven by the whispers of hypnopædia to consume, to spend, to indulge. Their strings pulled by the World Controller, who enacts a hegemony over their lives, a dominance where the many unknowingly uphold the very structure that ensnares them. The Alphas and Betas, aware yet silent, save for a few like Bernard who dare to question. In this interplay of castes, the heavy hand of capitalism's perceived oppression is made manifest.

In Huxley's creation, the bonds between souls are mere shadows. The novel draws no lines to separate its players, for even those who stand in the light are but hollow echoes. Here, he suggests that the rise of the machine and the market strips man of his will, his essence. Love is a ghost, and the peaks of emotion are leveled to the plain. Interactions are but surfaces, the men's talk of women reduced to the pneumatic, the women unabashed in their tales of encounters. The unquestioning acceptance of their place within the hierarchy speaks to the socioeconomic toll of capitalism. Their obedience, their unyielding role in the collective, mirrors the Marxist view of the proletariat, led to believe in their own supremacy so long as they consume, conform, and march in step with their fellows.

It was near four years past when I found myself enrolled in a course on Islam at CBC. A crucible of debate it was, with the class grappling fiercely over the nature of Islam itself, whether it bore hostility in its heart. The question lingers yet, more pertinent perhaps than it ever was. The shadow of 9/11 cast long, and I watched as the media scape shifted, from a scornful gaze upon Islam and its zealots to a peculiar tolerance within the bounds of America. In the year of 2001, it would have been unthinkable for a man named Barack Obama, whose lineage traced to Muslim roots, to stand as a presidential contender.

The life of the Prophet stirs my interest, for in it I see a dance of contradictions. The history I’ve known paints Muhammad as a conqueror, wielding the sword to spread the faith among tribes. Yet the biographers pen a different tale, casting him as a martyr, misunderstood and humble, drawing followers not by force but by the truth they perceived in his teachings. They came to him, so the story goes, as moths are drawn to flame.

There are echoes of another ministry, that of Jesus, in this narrative of Muhammad’s wonders. The multiplication of mutton and milk for forty men, a miracle reminiscent of the loaves and fishes. I sense the writers’ intent, to craft an image of a prophet unbothered by proof, instead living a life suffused with truth and miracles. Yet, such a portrayal seems to diminish the singular life of Christ, as though they would borrow glory from one to bestow upon another.

In the biography’s tales, one sees a pattern, a need to establish witness, to mark the conversion to Islam as a voluntary revelation. But the stories often wend their way through the mouths of others, a hearsay chain of so-and-so heard from so-and-so. It leaves the tales suspect, their truth diluted by the distance of voices.

What gnaws at me most is the elevation of Muhammad to a stature of saintly humility and wisdom, a gentle soul. Yet the chronicles of history seem to sing a different song, a discordant tune against this image. I wonder if those who follow Islam today perceive these truths, the history that lies beneath the legend of Muhammad’s ascent.

In the dust of centuries past, the teachings of the Nazarene lay like forgotten stones, left behind by those who sought to build upon them towers of doctrine reaching skyward. In the sweep of history, one sees the faith of Christ drawn ever further from its humble origins, a river swollen and diverted, its course altered by time and the hands of men. The world now turns with a restless awareness, a stirring in the hearts of many toward a horizon not yet seen. Those who cling to the old ways, rooted in tradition, stand steadfast, but their numbers wane, and their voices, though loud, may not carry the weight to halt the tide.

Amidst the faithful, a seed of understanding takes root, a reckoning with the layers laid upon the simple truth long ago. There will be a yearning, a hunger to peel back the years, to strip away the accretions of centuries, and to gaze once more upon the face of the Christ, unadorned and pure. It is a slow turning, a movement that may take the span of lifetimes, but it is inexorable. A great reversal looms on the horizon, a return to the ancient path, a shedding of the burdens of doctrine, down to the bare earth of the man from Galilee.

As this reversion sweeps across the lands, from the shores of the New World to the old streets of Europe, it will gather the faithful in its wake, drawing them together in a unity of purpose unseen for generations. The church will stand resolute, a shepherd to guide this flock, yet the diversity that once scattered the faithful like seeds upon the wind will coalesce into a singular vision. The distinctions that once divided them—denominations, creeds, and theologies—will blur into a harmony of belief, a testament to the power of a shared journey back to the source.

History is a tapestry woven with reversals, a testament to the cycles of human endeavor. The Romans once hunted the followers of Christ, only to later embrace the cross themselves. Our own nation has seen the chains of slavery broken, rising to a place where those once oppressed now lead. And so it will be with this coming reversion, as the faithful seek to unweave the threads of time, to return to the spring from which their faith first flowed. It is a journey that will be guided by a reading of the Nazarene’s words not as rigid law, but as parable and metaphor, a map to guide the soul.

In the mists of ancient days, before the man from Nazareth walked the dusty roads of Judea, there was only Judaism, the soil from which the new faith would grow. Monotheism, revelation, and the sacred texts of the Hebrews were the bedrock upon which the Romans, in their conquest of Jerusalem, found a people divided—not as one, but in the many faces of Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots, and the nameless multitudes who lived and died by the law. And so, one asks, what has become of this faith since those distant days?

In the gloom of the ironworks and the ceaseless clangor of industry, The Jungle lays bare the raw and unyielding truth of man's nature, a truth steeped in avarice and self-interest. Beneath the facade of civility lies a relentless quest for self-betterment, a pursuit blind to the plight of those who dwell in the shadows below. The tale unfolds within the labyrinthine corridors of the great factories, overseen by owners and managers whose eyes are fixed solely on the expansion of their empires. Their hearts are hardened against the cries of those trampled underfoot, the casualties of their relentless march toward progress. Upton Sinclair's vision is stark, his words painting the sky as a canvas of dark defilement, "The line of the buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky; here and there out of the mass rose the great chimneys, with the river of smoke streaming away to the end of the world." A testament to the disregard these titans hold for all that is caught in their wake, be it man or beast, the smoke rises unceasingly, a harbinger of ruin.

Within this realm of iron and smoke, the well-being of the laborer is cast aside, a mere afterthought in the ledger of wealth. The men who toil within are cogs in a machine, their lives exchanged for the promise of another dollar. Sinclair's words cut to the bone, "So from the top to bottom the place is simply a seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds; there is no loyalty or decency anywhere about it, there is no place in it where a man counted for anything against a dollar." The laborers are driven without mercy, their hours long and their recompense paltry, until the day they are discarded, without warning or recourse, to fend for themselves in a world devoid of safety nets. In this era of unbridled capitalism, laws are but whispers against the gale, and the owners reign unchecked, demanding ever more from their workers who toil under the weight of impossible demands. Though Sinclair's narrative does not voice it outright, the silent expectation is clear: endure the torment, for there is no salvation to be found. No agency offers solace, no hand extends in aid. The unions, conceived as bastions of hope, become yet another cog in the infernal machine, exploiting the very souls they claim to protect. The workers, ensnared in this relentless grind, are likened to slaves, "Here is a population, low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers; under such circumstances, immorality is exactly as inevitable, and as prevalent, as it is under the system of chattel slavery." Thus, the cycle turns unbroken, and the cries of the downtrodden echo unanswered into the void.

In the dim corridors of the mind where shadows weave their tales, Poe's "Dream-Land" stands, a testament to his own claim of mastery. Here, in the lines that speak of "Thulé," an echo from Virgil rises, whispering of that far island beyond Britain's grasp, the edge of what men dared to know. Virgil's voice indeed calls from the past, yet Poe's gaze wandered further, drawn to the Germanic titans of word. 

In this, the specter of Goethe looms large, for Karl J. Arndt, in his musings on "Poe’s Politian and Goethe’s Mignon," finds mirrors in their verses, a mimicry perhaps, or homage. The Oxford Companion to English Literature speaks of Goethe’s own Faust, a drama of poetic descent, unspooling over the years, its threads concluding in the year Goethe himself found his end, 1832. Within it, a fragment, "The King of Thulé," tells of a monarch whose heart was lost upon a goblet’s gift, his lady gone to the grave. The weight of memory bends him to drink and mourn until he casts his final treasure to the sea's depths and follows it with closed eyes into the abyss.

In Poe's "Dream-Land," echoes of this king's sorrowful tread can be felt, shadowed reflections of a soul adrift in drink and grief, perhaps a specter of Poe's own losses. Faust's tale found new life in the hands of H P Grattan in '42, mere moons before Poe's own pen inscribed "Thule" in "The Pit and the Pendulum." 

Twice "Thule" rings from Poe's collected voice, once in the pit's dark sway, twice in the land of dreams, a refrain that binds the pieces as kin. Within "Dream-Land," the traveler speaks of Thule's desolate expanse, a place where ghosts keep company and color fades to whispers. A land where Goethe's king might wander, burdened by loss and the specter of rule unclaimed, a place where Poe's imagination might find its reflection.

Through this, Goethe's shadow stretched across Poe's landscape, a presence felt through the tendrils of Tennyson's acclaim. Though the connection is woven by respect and the tides of literary fashion, it is in the echoes and the spaces between words that Poe found Goethe, and in turn, reflected him.

In the sun-drenched land of California, a question arises from the dust and echoes of commerce. Could a soul, wounded by a fall upon spilled applesauce in a grocer's lane, seek the judgment of punitive damages by revealing the store manager's malice? This, because twice he was told of the mess and yet, wrapped in the solitude of supper, let it linger for a half-hour unheeded.

In the halls of justice, a judge is unlikely to cast aside Jennifer Palmer’s claim for punitive recompense without due consideration. To weave such a claim, the plaintiff must unfurl evidence that the defendant’s deeds bore a willful and conscious neglect for the likely harm they sowed, and that such deeds were despicable in nature. Palmer might say that Martin should have foreseen the harm of not cleansing the spill, for in the months before her fall, many patrons of D&D had been felled by similar missteps. Knowing this, he still let the spill remain, a testament to his disregard. Her assertion of Martin's despicable nature may falter, yet it stands on the ground that six such slips had occurred in that fateful year, and still, Martin took no steps to ensure his store's safety.

That day, October 13, 2009, at the hour of five past the meridian, Rich Wayne, in the employ of D&D Markets, approached his overseer, Paul Martin, to speak of an applesauce spill. Martin, steeped in his meal, dismissed the matter, saying he lacked the time for the woes of the customer. Fifteen minutes later, another worker, Mary J. Haddigan, sounded the same alarm, and Martin, unyielding, replied in kind. At the half-hour mark, Jennifer Palmer stepped into the tale, slipping upon the spill, her back grievously hurt. Before Palmer's misfortune, five other such tales had unfolded at D&D in that same year. Now, Palmer seeks due redress for her hurt, both in compensatory and punitive terms, as we ponder the path of a motion to dim the punitive claim’s light.

In this golden state, one may recover punitive recompense for a breach not born of contract if the defendant wore the mantle of “oppression, fraud or malice.” Cal. Civ. Code, § 3294(a) (Lexis 2010) speaks thus. Malice, the law says, is a deed wrought to harm or, if not so intended, must be “despicable” and done with “a willful and conscious disregard of the rights or safety of others.” id. at § (c)(1). The courts have named a deed malicious when done with eyes wide to the peril it brings, yet the doer, with deliberation, let those perils come, as in Taylor v. Super. Ct. of Los Angeles Co., 598 P. 2d 853, 856 (Cal. 1979).

She had always harbored a yearning, a gnawing hunger that eluded fulfillment. It was a specter that took root around her fourteenth summer, as she waded into the tumult of adolescence, and it lingered still, three years hence, at seventeen. In those years, the amorphous need had coalesced into a desire for companionship rather than possession. Yet no boy stirred her interest. Some had attempted to court her with the clumsiness of youth, drawn by her allure, but all fell short of kindling any spark within her. She wrestled with this enigma, pondering the nature of her peculiar indifference, seeking the source of her anomaly with the earnestness of youth. The years of introspection yielded theories, but none substantial enough to anchor her speculation. And so she moved through her days, a soul adrift in her own quiet inquisition.

Home was a bastion of tranquility. Her parents were gentle souls, their discourse seldom marred by discord. They rarely quarreled, even with their daughter, save for the inevitable clashes with her burgeoning independence and spirited nature. She was the offspring of serenity, yet she injected into their lives a vibrancy that was both a counterpoint and a complement to their calm, endearing herself to all with her genuine warmth.

Today, however, tranquility shattered. As she wandered through the rooms, seeking the elusive muse, a cry pierced the air, sharp and sudden, borne from her mother's lips. Panic surged as she raced to the kitchen, her voice rising in urgent inquiry, "Mom?! Mom, what's wrong?!" Her mother lay prone, pain etched on her features, each breath a whispered "Ow." The girl rushed to her side, hand outstretched in a futile attempt to alleviate the hurt. "Ouch ... swee - ty, I ... need you to take me to - the hospital." The words tumbled out, compressed by agony, and the daughter knew her mother's suffering was profound. "Okay Mom, just tell me where I can pick you up." Her mother gestured, and in that instant, the girl was grateful for the strength she had honed in preparation for such unforeseen trials. She bore her mother to the car, laid her gently in the back, and drove with purpose.

The hospital loomed, a place of antiseptic odors and fraught with the specter of illness, but she was impervious to its atmosphere, her mind singularly fixated on her mother's plight. She carried her swiftly inside, her voice rising to summon aid, and they came, faces etched with concern, laying her mother upon a rolling bed with practiced haste. They whisked her away to urgent care, leaving the daughter ensconced in a cocoon of anxiety.

Her mother had tumbled from a stepping stool, reaching for a vase ensconced in the highest cabinet.

In the course of this study, the aim was to lay bare the truth that the adherence to what is known as the Mediterranean Diet, or the Med diet, as mirrored in a lofty alternate Mediterranean (aMed) diet score, carries with it a lesser burden of chronic heart disease and stroke and even the grim specter of stroke mortality. The aMed diet stands as a variant of the Med diet, distinguished by a greater presence of plant foods, plant proteins too, casting aside the common potato but embracing fruits, nuts, whole grains, and legumes, a favoring of monounsaturated fats over their saturated brethren, and a turn towards the bounty of the sea in fish, while the consumption of animal products and saturated fats wanes. A moderate measure of alcohol finds its place.

The chronicles of studies past have drawn forth an inverse association between the Med diet and the specter of death both total and cardiovascular, with interventions revealing the Med diet's prowess over a low-fat regimen, guiding to weight loss and a favorable tilt of the scales in cholesterol in those who carry the weight of obesity. Yet, these studies of old did not cast their gaze upon stroke or the mortality it brings.

This inquiry delved into the lives of 74,886 women, aged 38 to 63, their pasts unmarked by cardiovascular disease or diabetes, drawn from the Nurses' Health Study, a cohort woven from 121,700 female nurses across 11 states. Across the span from 1984 to 2004, six times over, an aMed diet score was drawn from the self-reported food frequency questionnaires, instruments crafted to capture the essence of their nutrient intake from the year gone by. A steadfast 95% of nurses remained tethered to this study through the two decades. The FFQs underwent the scrutiny of validation. The shadows of CHD, fatal CHD, and stroke were confirmed through the examination of medical and hospital records, autopsies, or the finality of death certificates. Where such records were absent, cases were deemed probable and gathered in, with some 17% of all strokes and 24% of nonfatal myocardial infarcts thus classified. Measures of body mass index, the smoke of cigarettes, the use of aspirin, the intake of multivitamins, menopausal status, and the postmenopausal hormone use were calculated for each FFQ, and from 1986 onward, the leisure pursuits of physical activity were noted.

To quell the capriciousness of random variation and to better capture the essence of long-standing dietary habits, cumulative averages of the aMed score from repeated FFQs were taken, melding together scores from two years past. Adjustments were made to account for the confounders, those beguiling factors that could cloud the truth, by adjusting for age, smoking, BMI, menopausal status, postmenopausal hormone use, multivitamin intake, alcohol intake, physical activity, and aspirin use.

Cox proportional-hazard modeling became the tool with which to discern the relation between an aMed score and the specter of CHD and stroke, separate models crafted for the fatal and the nonfatal, and for the varied strokes.

Greater fidelity to the Mediterranean way, as captured in a loftier aMed diet score, bore a kinship with a lesser risk of CHD and stroke in women. Across two decades of vigilance, 2391 new cases of CHD, 1763 strokes, and 1077 deaths by cardiovascular disease, the fatal CHD and strokes alike, were recorded. Those women who stood in the top aMed quintile found themselves at a diminished risk for both CHD and stroke when set against those in the bottom quintile, a relative risk standing at 0.71.

The sign proclaimed that Hitler lives in Burma. Ellen Page, known for her role in Juno, stood solitary on a street corner, a piece of cardboard hoisted aloft, the message scrawled in Sharpie, stark against the world. Burma, or Myanmar they call it now, a land under the yoke of a military junta, power seized in the coup of '62. In 2007, they rose, the people, the monks in their saffron robes leading the way, the streets alive with the spirit of a decade-long silence broken. The Saffron Revolution they named it, for the color of the robes, for the monks who dared the junta's wrath. At first, the government turned a blind eye, a charade of peace, but the tide turned red and the monasteries became battlegrounds, soldiers storming through sacred halls. Foreign eyes, the lenses of journalists, they were sought out, silenced. Kenji Nagai, a Japanese photojournalist, fell on September 27th, 2007, a casualty of witness. Thirteen dead, they say officially, but Colonel Hla Win, who turned against his own, whispers of thousands, of bodies uncounted and unseen.

This is the world's old song. Tyranny's hand upon the throats of the dissenters, a tale as aged as time itself. The Romans called their emperors divine, chosen by gods to rule with iron fist. In Japan, the emperors walked as gods among men, heralds of prosperity and ritual, and here in our own land, George W. Bush converses with Ted Haggard, a man steering fools under the banner of the Republic Party.

History is littered with such shadows. Tiananmen, June 4th, 1989, where the young and the intellectuals and the workers stood against their rulers. The numbers of the dead, a secret held tight by the Chinese government, spoke of a few hundred, but others tell of thousands fallen. Rwanda's blood-soaked earth in the '90s, Hutu against Tutsi, a government and its militia in lockstep, a genocide. And the specter of Hitler's Reich, where the Jewish people were hunted across nations, a dark chapter etched in the annals of time.

This tale is old, and still, it unfolds.

In the annals of jazz, Duke Ellington stands like a lone figure etched against a forlorn sky, his legacy a testament to the endurance and artistry that shaped his orchestra like the hand of a sculptor upon wet clay. His touch upon the piano keys whispers soft like the wind through the pines, yet as a composer, he weaves tapestries rich and complex, each thread a testament to the talent within his band. He built cathedrals of sound where the soloist roams free, yet he penned with precision, calling upon the unique voices of his players to illuminate the dark corners of his compositions. In this, he crafted a sound that was both singular and vast, a sound where each piece fit into a grand mosaic of innovation and brilliance.

The Grove Music dictionary speaks of Ellington's sound, a sound like no other, citing Creole Love Call, where the voice is wielded as a jazz instrument, a texture and color unburdened by words. This early work stands as a testament to his ability to compliment and elevate the soloist's style, a thread woven throughout his career. It moves slow, deliberate, a twelve bar blues with six choruses:

First, a call and response, voice and reeds, the voice smooth as river stones, then rough as the crags of a mountain.
Next, the muted trumpet sings, stretching the melody with blue notes that hang like twilight.
Then, a clarinet soars high, the piano beneath it a subtle dance.
The full band echoes, brass and reeds answering each other in echoes of the first.
The fifth chorus rises, reeds calling high, syncopated brass and rhythm beneath.
And finally, the voice and reeds return, the growl technique transforming the voice into an instrument itself.

Ellington's use of voice, a brushstroke of tone color, is a thread that runs through the tapestry of his work. In Hot and Bothered, a year hence, his orchestration is tight, his ear for tone color sharp. There, “Bubber” Miley's muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing engage in a call and response as rich as the earth, creating a sound that is both vocal and instrumental. And in It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing), these ideas find further expression, as Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton's muted trombone introduces the melody, a cornerstone in the architecture of Ellington's orchestra.

In the slow and relentless march of time, creatures shift and change, molded by forces both seen and unseen. One might wonder why these beings twist and turn upon their path of evolution, what barriers or guides might steer them along their course. The old wisdom of D’Arcy Thompson from the year nineteen and seventeen still whispers its quiet truth, that the heart of nature's forms eludes the grasp of numbers, an enigma yet unsolved. But the age has advanced, and in its wake, men have begun to use the language of mathematics to probe the secrets of the mollusk’s curving shell, through the journey of its life and the long tale of its kind (as pondered by Raup and Stanley in the year nineteen and eighty-one). With this study, we seek to weave together the strands of mathematical modeling and the tangible world of experiment, to uncover the hidden gears and levers that drive the evolution of the Prunum's form.

In this task, we took to the shadows cast by X-rays upon the shells of Prunum, seeking the lines and curves that tell their story. These we fed to the machine, the one they call CerioShell, born of Stone in nineteen and ninety-five, and from its calculations arose visions of shells that might be, to trace the limits of their potential change. These findings, in concert with the raw observations of nature, aim to cast light upon the great turning of macroevolution in this lineage.

Imagine a shell as a passage spiraling through the ages, each turn a whorl upon an unseen axis, the columella its spine. The whorls grow with a mind of their own, and a line, the suture, marks their boundaries. The greatest of these whorls is the last, the body whorl, while the spire rises above, its apex pointing to the heavens, and the base grounding it below. Out of this creation, the creature ventures forth through the aperture, its gateway to the world.

In viewing these shells, one might gaze from the apex, the base, the aperture, or the opposite side. And to count the whorls, one must see from above, finding the first suture and drawing a line to divide the shell, to reckon each turn from that mark, even to the quarter of a whorl.

Consider the shell as a series of open doors, each a moment in time, as the creature builds its home. The path of the aperture can be traced by the coordinates of its journey, the radius both wide and tall. This trajectory, a story woven in numbers, can be altered by shifting the variables, thus changing the blueprint of the mollusk's creation.

In the sprawling archipelago of Indonesia, the measure of life’s fragile beginnings has stood unmoved these past ten years, a stillness that echoes in the halls of hospitals and the quietude of rural clinics. While the nation strides toward the Millennium’s beckoning goals, meeting the calls for clean water and the sanctity of sanitation, the cries of mothers and the breath of infants tell a different tale. The path to the promised land of health for child and mother remains fraught, the goals set for 2015 a distant mirage. The reasons for this failure lie buried in the bones of a weakened system, a system in need of fortification rather than mere programmatic patchwork.

In the crowded rooms where life begins, there is now a greater presence of skilled hands, yet the promise is hollow. Seventy-two percent of births boast such attendance, but the skill is oft possessed by those whose hands are bound by tradition, midwives who cannot wield the tools of intervention when the blood flows too freely. The shadow of maternal death looms large, the specter of hemorrhage ever-present. And so the numbers that speak of progress are but whispers in the wind, masking the vast expanse of work yet undone. Meanwhile, the children suffer, their small bodies wracked with illness, and the hands of health professionals grow scarce in the treatment of their fevered sickness. The records of care after birth are fragmented and incomplete, yet they tell enough of a story—a narrative of neglect that spans the nation.

In the matter of Cesarean births, the statistics are telling, the figures languishing at a meager four percent, a testament to the inequities that divide this land. In the cities, the rate climbs to seven, yet in the remote corners, it falls to two. The disparity in service is a chasm carved by geography and wealth, the cities drawing the lion's share of care while the rural lands are left wanting. And within this division lies another tale of inequity, the chasm between rich and poor, a gap of twenty-seven percent in the use of services. The poor, ever at the margins, find themselves adrift in a sea of costs beyond their means.

As the nation contemplates its course, the question looms large: how best to mend this fabric of care? Should the focus be sharp and singular, a programmatic spear aimed at the heart of the issue, or should the strengthening of the system be broad and deep, encompassing the full breadth of life’s journey from womb to world? The allure of targeted programs is strong, their objectives clear and results swift. But the siren song comes with a price. To pour resources into one vein of the health sector is to starve another, to draw the lifeblood of human talent to where the money flows quickest, leaving other fields barren. The specter of international funding for HIV/AIDS casts a long shadow over family planning, a lesson in the perils of such a path. And so too, the proliferation of parallel programs breeds a forest of forms and a tangle of red tape, a bureaucracy that serves itself more than those it was meant to aid.

The annals of Popular Music stretch long in the shadows of time, a century's worth of sound and fury that resists confinement in neat little boxes. These sounds, unruly as a wild river, branch into countless tributaries—rap, rock, country, jazz, folk, and beyond—each spawning a profusion of sub-genres, sub-sub-genres, a tangled web of sonic exploration. Among these, the sub-genre of Heavy Metal has, over the past four decades, become a realm of manifold voices. Its expression is raw and unyielding, a tapestry woven from the darker threads of human emotion. This diversity, birthed from the genre's inception, revealed a flexibility that musicians seized upon, crafting sub-genres and further still until the music became a labyrinth of its own making. 

And now, as we stand amidst the cacophony of heavy metal's evolution, the essence of what defines it seems to blur, absorbed as it is with themes borrowed from other realms of music. Its roots, however, remain, for understanding the sprawling edifice of metal today demands a reckoning with its origins, its nature as a movement transcending mere genre.

Metal is a journey through shadow, a pursuit of the infinite. It is a sound of excess—more bass, more volume, more violence, more spectacle. It is less the primitive beat, more the virtuoso's touch; the musicians are craftsmen, their mastery evident in every note. Metal, unsurprisingly, is a journey often fueled by the mind-altering haze of drugs. In the mid-seventies, a psychedelic tide swept minds to the brink, birthing records that spoke in tongues of madness and otherworldly visions. These qualities, visceral and dark, struck a new chord in the music scene, a scene where much of what was popular dared not tread into such shadowed realms. Successive waves of metal drew from these dark waters, echoing the Romantic Era’s penchant for the visceral and sublime. The darkness runs like a black thread through the lyrics, a staple of the movement, a whisper of the abyss.

Consider, if you will, the song Helter Skelter, the Beatles' own foray into the depths. It is a song that ascends and descends, a reflection of the mind's tumultuous journey under the influence. Some whisper it to be among the first born of Heavy Metal, a response to the Rolling Stones’ own darkened tune. The Beatles, in their rivalry, sought to prove they could summon the heaviness of the Stones, casting this track into the world from the depths of The White Album.

In the years before the surrealists set their dreams to canvas, Henri Rousseau crafted his own visions from the fabric of his soul. The Dream, painted in 1910, stands as a testament not merely to the wonder of lands traversed in dreams but to the yearnings and aspirations that stirred within Rousseau's heart. Here is a woman cast in awe, and here too lies Rousseau, a painter longing for the embrace of recognition and the praise of his peers. From the outset, he was beset by the vexing choice: to mimic the styles that would grant him entry into the hallowed halls of the art world or to forge his own path, unshackled and defiant.

To lay eyes upon The Dream, one must first know the dreamer himself. Born May 21, 1844, in the shadowed town of Laval in the northwest of France, Rousseau's beginnings were humble. His father, a tinsmith by trade, lived a life of modest means. Rousseau's hands knew no art in his youth, only the labor of a gabelou, a toiler of municipal tolls, though the world knew him falsely as a douanier. In his personal life, tragedy was a constant companion. The death of his wife Clémence, preceded by the loss of eight children, left him with only a daughter, Julia, and a heart heavy with grief. With brush and canvas, Rousseau sought solace, a new dawn in the midst of despair. Unlike his contemporaries who painted the peasantry with romance, Rousseau was of the folk, a dreamer of dreams that echoed the common man's heart.

To yearn for acceptance is a human thing, and given his journey, Rousseau's fervent desire to be embraced by the art world is understandable. Untrained, commencing his true calling late, he labored in the shadow of giants. Recognition came slowly, only as Matisse was carving his own niche. In Modern French Painters, Jan Gordon speaks of the two as rivals yet not, their purposes diverging. Matisse, a man driven by the fear of banality, while Rousseau's wish was to paint with such convention that he might be welcomed into the Artiste Français. Yet in that desire lay the paradox of his existence.

In the quiet corridors of thought where the world’s thinkers have often wandered, there lies a tether binding ethics to aesthetics, truth to beauty. At the core of it all, there is a reason, something elemental. Keats, with his Grecian urn, whispers to us that beauty is truth and truth beauty. That alone is the knowing granted to us in this world. Our journey through life imparts knowledge through the rigors of education or the trials of experience, yet there are things deeper still, understood without instruction. Ethics and aesthetics, you see, are less commandments than they are whispers of understanding. Our exploration of morality and art seeks not to lay down laws but to uncover the mysteries of what makes art resonate or an action noble.

In the telling of art’s worth or moral’s measure, the conversation dances around but never quite holds the essence in its grasp. Take da Vinci’s Mona Lisa, a subject of myriad discussions—foreground, background, contrast, and culture. Yet none capture why it stands as art. When asked of a beloved piece, a soul might say, “There’s just something about it,” before delving into critique. Art and morality resist reduction to mere qualities. As O’Connor wisely notes, a story unveils what mere statements cannot. All descriptions of literature leave something transcendent. Ethics, too, shares this nature. Wittgenstein muses that ethics cannot be spoken, for it transcends. It is this ineffable quality, this je ne sais quoi, that is the true strength of art and morality, forging the link between them.

Morality and art wend their way to us in the realm of the noumenal, as Kant might term it. They touch us in ways that defy full explanation. Literature, especially, bears this bond with the moral. As McKean observes, literature’s distinction lies in its moral quality. Other arts might escape such standards, but literature’s very essence is intertwined with the values of life. Living is entwined with values, and literature matters because it reflects those very values back to us.

In the land of Germany as it stands now, a robust and unified presence lingers. From the shadowed embrace of the Alps in München to the northern reach of Kiel by the Baltic Sea, the cultural tapestry weaves its way through the country. It is felt along the banks of the Rhine in Köln, threading its path to Dresden where the Elbe flows. To see Germany's culture as a singular entity is to overlook the myriad threads that form its history, echoing from tribes long past.

Germania, the cradle of the Germanic soul, holds a name whose roots are tangled in scholarly debate. Tacitus, in his accounts, spoke of the Tungrians, a tribe he claimed once bore the name German before they ventured across the Rhine to clash with the Gauls. It was Julius Caesar who first inscribed “Germanus” in his chronicles of the Gallic Wars, a term lifted from the Gauls to set apart those he had vanquished from those who stood unconquered, the latter crossing the Rhine with a mischievous intent. Some, in their conjectures, propose it was a Gaulish word for a neighbor, while others see it as tied to the Germanic spear, the ger, or the Old Irish garim, a shout that marked the Germans as loud and fierce.

Tacitus, in his stoic prose, penned “De Origine et situ Germanorum” in AD 98, speaking of a people aboriginal, untouched by the tides of migration. He mused that no man would forsake the fertile lands of Asia or Africa for the harsh terrain and sullen skies of Germania unless it was the call of home. For who in their right mind would leave Rome for such a place? Not the Romans, not then. They sent their armies to the edges of Germania, thirsting for its bounty, yet always they turned back to the sprawling heart of their empire. As the Germanic tribes took form in the first century, they lingered on the empire's periphery, trading and serving among the Roman ranks, their skills honed by the land they called home (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17).

In the play Twelfth Night, the shroud of disguise wends its way through the soul’s corridors, a tool both cunning and perilous. This masquerade, crafted to deceive, must ultimately be cast off, lest the wearer be consumed by its shadow, leaving only echoes of identity behind. The unraveling of deception bears its own burden—alienation, a severing of bonds once held dear. Thus, one stands at a crossroads, the heart torn between the sanctity of self and the fragile tapestry of human connection. For while some may look upon the ruse with indifference, others shall find offense in the unmasking, their trust shattered like glass upon the stones.

The intricate dance of deception twines with the reversal of gender roles, raising questions that linger like specters in the mind's recesses. Chief among them is the bewildering query: why? What compels one to forsake their own visage and don the garb of another gender? Viola's plight answers with the voice of survival: "I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249). In lands unknown, Viola cloaks herself in masculinity to stave off danger, her guise a shield against the world’s brute forces. Yet this guise estranges her from the womenfolk, severing her from their solace and strength. Her deception, so artfully wrought, ensnares Olivia in a web of confusion, blurring the lines between Cesario and Sebastian, leading to a love misplaced: “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138). And still, she carries the weight of unspoken ardor, a flame flickering between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1.260-261).

In this tangled skein, Twelfth Night speaks to the modern soul, revealing how deceit may unlock the heart’s hidden chambers, drawing forth desires long buried. The shadows of Olivia and Orsino’s hearts suggest yearnings unspoken, desires unbidden, brought to light by Viola’s masquerade. Does Olivia’s heart lean toward Cesario for the semblance of manhood, or does it whisper of a deeper truth, a love for women that dares not speak its name? Yet, it seems more likely that Olivia mirrors the follies of her time, where judgment clings to the surface, to the fleeting beauty of countenance. Her swift transfer of affection from Cesario to Sebastian, her embrace of Cesario/Viola as kin rather than lover, sings of this transformation: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315).

The German colonial dominion, a vast and unruly beast, was remarked upon by many for its cruelty, most vividly in the blood-drenched lands of German South West Africa where the Ovaherero and Nama peoples met their grim fate. Yet an empire so sprawling as this cannot be easily reckoned with a single tale of savagery. It was a tapestry of many colors, each colony a world unto its own with laws and manners as diverse as the lands they governed. In the realm of education too was such variance. When the British laid claim to German East Africa, known as Tanganyika, in the year 1919, they encountered a multitude of Africans not only schooled but literate. The Germans had sown seeds of learning across their holdings in Kamerun and beyond, earning the admiration of those who chronicled such endeavors.

Yet in the arid expanse of South West Africa, what they now call Namibia, the story was a different one. There, unlike in the green expanses of East Africa where the state had seen fit to build schools and take charge of educating the native populace, the burden fell almost entirely to missionaries, who struggled with scant aid from the government. It was the Europeans who received the state’s largess, with schools established for their benefit and missionary efforts therein strictly overseen and supported. The legacy of these policies lingered long after the Germans departed, leaving behind a land where the vast majority of its people remained untouched by the light of learning, their minds unawakened, their hands unlettered. The reasons for this divergence lay buried in the complex soil of social, political, and economic circumstance. This paper seeks to unearth these factors, guided by fresh inquiry into the hearts and minds of settlers and those who ruled them.

The annals of education under the German flag are rich, penned mostly in the mother tongue of those who sought to document the ways of teaching in lands far from home. These early works served to describe what was, laying bare the bones of the educational systems in the colonies. Later, voices speaking in English broadened the conversation, comparing the schools of different colonies and plumbing the depths of their particularities. They revealed a world of contrasts. Among these, Cohen’s study stands as a keystone, examining the schools of South West Africa and East Africa and unraveling the threads that set them apart. He points to the settlers of South West Africa, a people drawn to its mild climes amidst the desert's embrace, as a key to understanding the peculiarities of its schools.

South West Africa, compared to the other lands held by Germany, offered a climate more forgiving, though much of it was swallowed by the barrenness of desert. The Europeans flocked to it, finding it more welcoming than other colonies. By 1913, the land bore witness to nearly 15,000 white souls, while East Africa, holding the next largest gathering of settlers, counted but 5,336.

There was a time when the United States of America and the lands of Mexico were bound in a rivalry that stretched across the years like a shadow over the desert, a span of fifty-seven years from 1836 to 1893. It was a time marked by conflict, the high-water mark of which was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848. Here the United States moved with force and took from Mexico the lands of Texas and what would become the American Southwest. Other confrontations followed, a simmering flame that would last until just before the Great War. These two nations were locked in a struggle, their differences rooted deep in matters of faith and custom, and in the clash of their material desires. 

But this tale is not unique in the chronicles of nations. For those who share a border often find themselves at odds, their interests clashing like the meeting of two rivers. The United States and Mexico were no different from many such enduring rivalries that mark the history of neighboring lands. David M. Pletcher once spoke of the long shadows cast by these old American diplomatic problems, their roots tangled in the lands of Mexico and Cuba. These are the two that sit closest to the heart of the United States, while other brethren in Latin America have known times of peace and good relation.

So it was that religious discord drove a wedge between these two nations, a rift as old as the hills, and no stranger to the annals of human history. As Sally Frahm tells it, in those days past, Americans set themselves against the creeds of Catholicism and the rule of monarchy, just as in the later years they would stand against the specters of fascism and communism. This was a struggle of ideologies, not unlike the Cold War that would follow, yet rooted in the faith of the people, a legacy inherited from the distrust that lay between English and Spanish blood. A legacy that forged a barrier to peace between the United States and Mexico.

In the reckoning of Diehl and Goerts, there were seventeen disputes that marked the years of this rivalry. Most of them were born of territorial matters, of raids across borders and the lawlessness of the frontier. Bandits and outlaws ranged wild, a trouble that lingered until both nations brought forth their military might to tame the edges of their lands. Yet, as the years passed, the rivalry began to wane. Schmitt tells us it was because Mexico found itself in need of what the United States could offer, and the ambitions of America turned from the hunger for lands to the pursuit of economic influence in Mexico in the late days of the nineteenth century.

Fifteen years past I found myself felled by an ailment unknown to me before. A sudden and unwelcome visitor that took hold and did not let go.

I once wore the garb of a nurse. A choice born not from dreams but from necessity, a yearning for the security denied me in younger days.
